document.docAuthor: Ruiz, Gustavo R. S., Maddison, Wayne P. & Galiano, Maria Elena
document.docTitle: Mago brimodes Ruiz & Maddison & Galiano 2019, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the concept of Mago O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1882, and proposal of a new genus (Araneae: Salticidae: Amycini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the concept of Mago O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1882, and proposal of a new genus (Araneae: Salticidae: Amycini)

figureCitation.captionText-0: FIGURES 10–13. Mago brimodes sp. nov.: 10–12 male (10 dorsal; 11 laterodorsal; 12 frontal); 13 female, dorsal. © 2015 W. Maddison, released under a Creative Commons Attribution (CC-BY) 3.0 license.
figureCitation.captionText-1: FIGURES 14–17. Mago brimodes sp. nov.: 14–16 male (14 face; 15 left chelicera, ventral; 16 lateral); 17 female, lateral.
figureCitation.captionText-2: FIGURES 18–27. Mago brimodes sp. nov.: 18–22 male (18 palp; 19 leg I; 20 leg II; 21 leg III; 22 leg IV, lateral); 23–27 female (23 palp; 24 leg I; 25 leg II; 26 leg III; 27 leg IV, lateral). Scale bar equals carapace length.
figureCitation.captionText-3: FIGURES 28–34. Mago brimodes sp. nov.: 28–32 male (28 left palp, ventral; 29 same, retrolateral; 30 mouthparts, ventral; 31 same, laterodistal; 32 sternum and left coxae, ventral); 33–34 epigyne (33 ventral; 34 cleared, dorsal).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Types.
Male holotype from Manakin Trail, Reserva Canandé, Esmeraldas , Ecuador ( 0.5270–0.5265°N , 79.2092– 79.2089°W ),
310 m
,
19 Aug. 2011
, Maddison , Piascik & Vega (WPM#11-155), deposited in QCAZ .
Female paratype with same data, except for Quail Trail ( 0.5253–0.5252°N , 79.2076–79.2073°W ),
320 m
(WPM#11-130), deposited in QCAZ
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 10–13.
Mago brimodes
sp. nov. :
10–12 male (10 dorsal; 11 laterodorsal; 12 frontal); 13 female, dorsal. © 2015 W. Maddison, released under a Creative Commons Attribution (CC-BY) 3.0 license.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology. An adjective from the Greek (
brimodes
= stern or indignant), due to the thick eyebrow, and their habit of holding the legs tight against the body, as if a person frowning and with arms crossed.

Diagnosis. Male differs from that of
M. intentus
by having a shorter embolus ( Fig. 28 ; compare to Fig. 6 ). Female is the only one known in the genus ( Figs 33–34 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 14–17.
Mago brimodes
sp. nov. :
14–16 male (14 face; 15 left chelicera, ventral; 16 lateral); 17 female, lateral.

FIGURES 18–27.
Mago brimodes
sp. nov. :
18–22 male (18 palp; 19 leg I; 20 leg II; 21 leg III; 22 leg IV, lateral); 23–27 female (23 palp; 24 leg I; 25 leg II; 26 leg III; 27 leg IV, lateral). Scale bar equals carapace length.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation. Males with smaller palps also have smaller mastidia.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality ( Ecuador ).
